Title:
Phylogeography of Icelandic Agrostis (Poaceae) from
geothermally heated and non-heated areas
Abstract:
Abstract Premise of the study: Geothermal areas create
living conditions strikingly different from their surroundings. In
Iceland, grasses of the genus Agrostis L. (Poaceae) grow on up to 70 Â°C
hot soils. The same species also occur in non-heated areas, making this
an excellent study system for thermal and climate change research. The
aim of this study was to test whether geothermal populations are
genetically distinct from non-thermal populations to provide a
phylogeographic framework for experimental studies. Methods: An
extensive phylogeny was built using whole chloroplast genome (plastome)
data, focussing on two of the three species in Iceland (A. stolonifera
and A. vinealis), sampled from Icelandic heated and non-heated areas and
their worldwide distributions. Key results: Bayesian analyses show that
A. stolonifera samples from the two hottest sites form a strongly
supported clade. All other Icelandic A. stolonifera form a boreal clade,
together with samples from Norway and Greenland. This suggests that a
potentially more heat tolerant lineage of A. stolonifera colonised the
geothermal soils seperatly. In contrast, almost all Icelandic A.
vinealis samples form a single clade, indicating that Icelandic A.
vinealis does not comprise a special geothermal lineage. However, their
close relationship to other geothermal species suggests that A. vinealis
might be pre-adapted to heat. Conclusion: These findings suggest a role
for both in situ and ancestral adaptations during establishment in
geothermal areas, highlighting the peculiarity of geothermal systems as
well as the importance of a phylogeographic perspective for furthering
understanding of the special plant communities that thrive there.
